post:
IndiaMART has given me the platform to grow, lead, and contribute in meaningful ways, and for that, I will always be grateful.

As I step into a new chapter, I carry with me the values, memories, and lessons that only 11 years of deep experience can provide.

Hereâ€™s to new beginningsâ€”and eternal gratitude to the place that helped shape who I am today.

This journey has been one of immense discipline, late nights, sacrifices, and relentless focus. Clearing one of the toughest professional exams in India wasn't just about passing papers â€” it was about proving to myself that consistency and courage truly pay off.

To every student who feels overwhelmed or stuck â€” trust the process. Your effort, no matter how small it seems now, is building something bigger.

A heartfelt thank you to my family, mentors, and peers who believed in me even during the moments I doubted myself

This journey was anything but easy-full of late nights, self-doubt, sacrifices, and constant pressure. But today, it all feels worth it.

There were moments I wanted to give up, when the syllabus felt never-ending and results day felt like judgment day. But I held on and Iâ€™m so glad I did.

A big thank you to my family, friends, mentors, and everyone who supported me through this rollercoaster. Your belief in me made all the difference.

This one year has been a journey of learning, unlearning, growth, and immense self-discovery. But more importantly, it has reminded me that no accomplishment is ever truly personal â€” it's a collective victory shaped by those who stand by you, support you, and believe in you.

One memory Iâ€™ll never forget: my Dadaji purposely staying up and walking in at 2 AM during my study nights â€” just to sit beside me, talk for a bit, and ease the weight of it all. That quiet support meant the world.

To those who checked in, believed, pushed, and prayed â€” thank you. This is as much your milestone as mine.

Feeling nothing but gratitude as I take the next steps.

Walking into the office where products Iâ€™ve admired for years are built â€” and now contributing to them â€” has been a dream come true. From the excitement of onboarding to diving into impactful projects, every day has been filled with learning, collaboration, and inspiration.

A huge shoutout to the people who helped me reach here

To every coach who pushed me, every teammate who lifted me, and every young athlete who reminds me why this journey matters

I wear this regalia with gratitude â€” not as an endpoint, but as a call to keep building legacies that outlast trophies. The field gave me purpose. Today, academia reminds me that purpose has a platform.

In a world where work often takes center stage, itâ€™s easy to forget that what truly moves us forward is people. Their energy, positivity, and willingness to lift each other up is what builds real culture.

I feel so grateful to work with a team that chooses to appreciate, encourage, and celebrate each other every day.

These little thank you notes mean the world, a reminder that great teams are not just about deadlines and deliverables, but about kindness, recognition, and genuine connection.

A heartfelt thank you to each and every one of you who supported, encouraged, and believed in me. Winning this means so muchâ€”not just because of the title, but because of the incredible people who stood by me and shared this journey.

Your votes, your kind words, and your unwavering faith have been overwhelming. This isnâ€™t just my winâ€”itâ€™s ours. I promise to carry this responsibility with sincerity, integrity, and dedication.

Gratitude beyond words

When I genuinely help someone and they say â€œThank you.â€
That unexpected smile. That relief in their eyes. That small message of gratitude.
A heartfelt thank you to our incredible team, partners, and God for guiding us every step. Excited for the bright future ahead!

To the leadership team, colleagues, mentors, peers, and extended partners â€” thank you for believing in me, guiding me, and pushing me to raise the bar every single time.

Itâ€™s hard to sum up the experience in a few lines, but hereâ€™s my best attempt..

Though I turn this page, the learnings and relationships Iâ€™ve built here will always stay close to my heart. Momentive will always hold a special place in my journey.
Most company cultures donâ€™t fail from toxicity.They fail from neglect
Most company cultures donâ€™t fail from toxicity.They fail from neglect
In any organization, if juniors leave quickly while a bunch of seniors have been there for years,that's a sign of a toxic environment.
While others say culture ~ We build it! Work hard and chill harder at ObserveNow
Culture is not a checkpointâ€”it's the foundation.
Skills can be taught. Culture? Thatâ€™s lived. It means hiring people who value what your company values â€” curiosity, integrity, collaboration, hunger, and ownersh
Wish to drive a great culture, be conscious about what to discuss and when to avoid. Office politics often starts from the TOP
Growth becomes meaningful when itâ€™s anchored in purpose and empowered by a culture that prioritizes people.
Every time someone says â€œThatâ€™s not how we do it here!â€An opportunity quietly walks out the door.
Every founder builds two thingsA product and a culture. One scales. The other compounds.
If a well-designed, thought-out change is not working, the answer lies with culture.
Culture is no longer a â€˜nice to haveâ€™ â€” itâ€™s the operating system of how people relate, grow, and thrive at work

Your people arenâ€™t just employees.Theyâ€™re your reflection.

When I look at my team, I donâ€™t just see titles or roles.

I see:
â†’ The values we stand for
â†’ The clarity weâ€™ve built together
â†’ The leadership we choose to model

Because people mirror the culture you build.

If you cut corners â€” they will too.

If you show up with heart and discipline â€” theyâ€™ll rise with you.

Thatâ€™s why I donâ€™t just train people.

I invest in culture.
that culture isn't just about free snacks and bean bags. It's about creating a space where everyone can do their best work!

During interviews, candidates are often assessed for culture fitâ€”how well they align with the existing team.

However, it's equally important to consider culture addâ€”what new perspectives or experiences they bring.

Culture add can introduce fresh ideas, diverse thinking, and creative problem-solving. It helps break the mold and encourages innovation within teams.
 
By focusing on culture add, we open doors to growth and future-proof our organization.

If your best employees are leaving,It's not them.


It's your culture.

They don't leave companies, names or titles.
They leave toxic work environments.
Salary attracts talents, but respect and recognitions help to retain those talents. But a great work culture helps those talents to thrive.
A companyâ€™s work culture is reflected in how employees feel on Sunday night about going to work on Monday.
Culture is not pizza Fridays. It is trust, safety and empathy.

Itâ€™s not the pay â€” itâ€™s the place.. 

Salary is never the first reason employees leave organisations. Itâ€™s usually the last.

1. Toxic culture â€“ It drains energy and impacts mental health. Even good pay canâ€™t fix a bad environment.

2. Lack of appreciation â€“ Effort without recognition feels empty. A simple â€œwell doneâ€ goes a long way.

3. Being ignored â€“ When ideas are dismissed and voices unheard. People stop trying where they feel invisible.

4. No growth â€“ Repetition without 
learning leads to frustration. Everyone seeks progress, not just a paycheck.

Yes, salary matters.
But respect, culture, and growth matter more.

When a company provides a flexible workspace and freedom over working hours, it fosters a flat approach to incremental innovation, allowing employees to complete their work with passion. Work becomes enjoyable, sparking creativity without pressure. This kind of culture builds innovative ideas and reinforces a flat structure where everyone is equally important. As a result, employees are more likely to love their work.

In an industry where talent is the core asset, pushing longer work hours without revisiting compensation, flexibility, or employee experience is not only disheartening but also unsustainable.

Work culture must evolve with the times â€” respecting work-life balance, valuing output over hours, and aligning with market standards in both pay and people policies.

Employees deserve more than extended hours â€” they deserve respect, recognition, and real rewards.

To all organizations out there: Please build cultures that attract and retain talent through empathy, not exhaustion.
Employees Don't Leave Companies-They Leave Managers Who Make Them Feel Worthless.

90% of an organizationâ€™s work culture depends on a managerâ€™s behavior.
It all comes down to:

How mid-level managers deal with their teams
How they support and onboard new team members
How fairly they treat everyone
How unbiased their decisions are
How responsibly they own up to mistakes
How they give credit to the ones who truly deserve it
How they make the team feel engaged and motivated
How they build a team others would actually wish to be a part of
But hereâ€™s the harsh truth:

Only 1 in 10 managers truly strive to build such teams.
The rest are busy chasing their own promotions, recognition, and personal gains.

If organizations started taking anonymous feedback from team members about their managers, a lot of hidden issues would surface.

And maybeâ€”just maybeâ€”weâ€™d start creating workplaces that people genuinely enjoy.

Iâ€™m not saying all managers are toxic. But yes, most of them need serious work.

Managers are the face of the teamâ€”and of the company.

They must be fair, transparent, and genuinely invested in their people.
Amazing colleagues, supportive leadership, and a culture that fosters growth â€“ couldn't ask for a better workplace

Playing football after work was almost treated like a compliance violation.

1. Why are you wasting time?
2. Games are for kids!
3. The office is for work, not for fun.

Meanwhile, at places that get it, folks show up after hours, with football kits, TT bats, yoga mats, having the time of their lives.

No judgment. Just balance.

Imagine that:-
Adults playing games, and still managing to build world-class products. Shocking.

If fun threatens your culture, maybe itâ€™s your culture that needs fixing"},

In the Margins.
A new column that I plan to share on what doesnâ€™t sit neatly at the centre.
Not the loudest voices.
Not the cleanest categories.
Not the headlines, the talking points, or the five-point plans.
But the texture beneath.
The ideas in draft.
The uncomfortable thoughts. The cultural contradictions. The things we almost say but donâ€™t.
In the Margins is where Iâ€™ll write about the edges â€” of culture, communication, creativity, work, influence, technology, and the performance of it all.
Itâ€™s not meant to be reactive or urgent.
 Itâ€™s meant to be attentive.

Giving salary is not a personal favor; it's a contractual obligation and payment for work performed.

Employees are entitled to their wages for the time & hard work they put in. A salary is earned compensation for hard work, competence, and knowledge, not a gift or act of kindness!

A good work culture company always promotes their employees for their hard work and contribution towards the firm
